STDIO Utility Functions
utils

Detailed Description

Purpose: This module provides standard input/output utilities for Ambiq Micro devices. It enables printf-style output, character handling, and string formatting for embedded applications requiring console or debug output capabilities. The utilities support multiple output channels and formatting options.

https://support.ambiqmicro.com/hc/en-us/articles/360040441631

Key Features

  1. Printf Functions: Complete printf-style formatting capabilities.
  2. String Conversion: Number-to-string conversion for various formats.
  3. 64-bit Support: Full 64-bit integer handling and formatting.
  4. Floating Point: Float-to-string conversion with precision control.
  5. Buffer Management: Static buffer allocation for memory efficiency.
  6. Text Translation: Newline translation and text mode support.

Functionality

  • Provide printf, sprintf, snprintf formatting functions
  • Support 32-bit and 64-bit integer formatting
  • Handle floating-point number conversion
  • Perform hexadecimal and decimal string conversion
  • Manage text mode translation (CR/LF handling)
  • Support variable argument list processing
  • Enable character output redirection
  • Provide buffer overflow protection

Usage

  1. Initialize stdio with am_util_stdio_printf_init()
  2. Set text translation mode if needed
  3. Use printf functions for formatted output
  4. Configure character output redirection
  5. Handle buffer management for large strings

Configuration

  • Printf Buffer: Configurable buffer size for formatted output
  • Text Mode: Optional CR/LF translation for terminal output
  • Character Output: Function pointer for output redirection
  • Memory Alignment: 4KB alignment for Apollo5 devices
  • Format Support: Decimal, hexadecimal, and floating-point formats

◆ am_util_stdio_printf()

uint32_t am_util_stdio_printf ( const char * pcFmt,
... )

A lite version of printf()

Parameters
*pcFmt- Pointer to formatter string

See am_util_stdio_sprintf() for more details.

Returns
uint32_t representing the number of characters printed.

◆ am_util_stdio_printf_init()

void am_util_stdio_printf_init ( am_util_stdio_print_char_t pfnCharPrint)

Sets the interface for printf calls.

Parameters
pfnCharPrint- Function pointer to be used to print to interface

This function initializes the global print function which is used for printf. This allows users to define their own printf interface and pass it in as a am_util_stdio_print_char_t type.

void am_util_stdio_scanf_init ( am_util_stdio_get_char_t pfnCharGet)

Sets the interface for scanf calls.

Parameters
pfnCharGet- Function pointer to be used to get from interface

This function initializes the global scanf function which is used for scanf. This allows users to define their own scanf interface and pass it in as a am_util_stdio_get_char_t type.

◆ am_util_stdio_snprintf()

uint32_t am_util_stdio_snprintf ( char * pcBuf,
uint32_t n,
const char * pcFmt,
... )

Format data into string.

Parameters
*pcBuf- Pointer to the buffer to store the string
n- number of arguments
*pcFmt- Pointer to formater string

A lite version of vsprintf(). Currently handles the following specifiers: c s %[0][width]d (also i) %[0][width]u %[0][width]x

Note than any unrecognized or unhandled format specifier character is simply printed. For example, "%%" will print a '' character.

Returns
uint32_t representing the number of characters printed.

const char * pcFmt,
... )

Format data into string.

Parameters
*pcBuf- Pointer to the buffer to store the string
*pcFmt- Pointer to formater string

A lite version of vsprintf(). Currently handles the following specifiers: c s %[0][width]d (also i) %[0][width]u %[0][width]x

Note than any unrecognized or unhandled format specifier character is simply printed. For example, "%%" will print a '' character.

Returns
uint32_t representing the number of characters printed.

◆ am_util_stdio_strtoul()

uint32_t am_util_stdio_strtoul ( const char * str,
char ** endptr,
int base )

Converts strings to 32-bit unsigned integers.

Parameters
*str- Pointer to the string to convert
**endptr- strtoul will set this to the char after the converted num
base- Base of the number as written in the input string.

This function was implemented in a way similar to the strtoul function found in the C standard library. It will attempt to extract a numerical value from the input string, and return it to the caller. Invalid input strings will return a value of zero.

Returns
uint32_t representing the numerical value from the string.

◆ am_util_stdio_terminal_clear()

void am_util_stdio_terminal_clear ( void )

Clear the terminal screen.

This function clears a standard terminal screen.

◆ am_util_stdio_textmode_set()

bool am_util_stdio_textmode_set ( bool bSetTextTranslationMode)

Text mode translates linefeed (
) characters to carriage return/ linefeed (CR/LF) combinations in printf() and sprintf() functions.

Parameters
bSetTextTranslationMode- true: Do LF to CR/LF translation. false: Don't do the text mode translation.

This function causes the printf() and sprintf() functions to translate newline characters (\n) into CR/LF (\r\n) combinations.

Returns
Previous mode.

◆ am_util_stdio_vprintf()

uint32_t am_util_stdio_vprintf ( const char * pcFmt,
va_list pArgs )

Format data into string. (va_list implementation)

Parameters
*pcFmt- Pointer to formatter string
*pArgs- Pointer to extended arguments

A lite version of vsprintf(). Currently handles the following specifiers: c s %[0][width]d (also i) %[0][width]u %[0][width]x %[.precision]f

Note than any unrecognized or unhandled format specifier character is simply printed. For example, "%%" will print a '' character.

Returns
uint32_t representing the number of characters printed.
